room learners' ability to set goals that enhance their personal and academic growth.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Candidates identify and use culturally responsive and relevant classroom management strategies.Successful application of theory and practice are essential course experiences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Candidates are responsible for transportation to off-site placements.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Current background check is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(2 credit hours) Prerequisite: Formal admission into Clinical (Candidate status).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: EDU 323, EDU 351, EDU 400 and EDU 411.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EDU 312 - Instructional Strategies for Diverse Learners (3) Recognizing the increasing plurality of learners in the United States, this course provides students with an understanding of classroom population diversity and emphasizes a variety of differentiated instructional strategies.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ation diversity and emphasizes a variety of differentiated instructional strategies.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Focusing on development of inclusive educational practices in both traditional and virtual settings, students will be able to acknowledge and identify student differences and adapt instruction based on racial, ethnic, cultural, linguistic and socio-economic variations.Candidates are responsible for transportation to off-site placements.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Current background check is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Acceptance into the Educator Preparation Program (Provisional Status) and EDU 201 or EDU 301.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: EDU 375.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EDU 321 - Disciplinary Literacy Methods (3) This course focuses on discipline-specific literacy development and offers instruction and practice in various strategies designed to integrate and reinforce reading and writing for meaning in all subject areas.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ned to integrate and reinforce reading and writing for meaning in all subject areas.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Emphasis is on using texts and other printed material to facilitate reading comprehension and concept development.Both traditional and virtual settings are utilized.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Candidates are responsible for transportation to off-site placements.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Current background check is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Acceptance into the Educator Preparation Program (Provisional status), and EDU 201 or EDU 301.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: MTH 309, EDU 324, EDU 325, and EDU 376.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EDU 323 - Reading & Writing K-5 (4) This course provides teacher candidates with an understanding of the processes involved in the ability to read and write.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is placed on the development of oral language; the phonological awareness continuum; print and alphabetic knowledge; phonics instruction; and vocabulary, fluency and comprehension.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

e study may take the form of a thesis or a significant engineering- related project.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Both involve individual study and research under the guidance of a faculty supervisor and culminate in a formal paper that follows a division-specific format.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120, English Proficiency Exam, junior standing, Computer Science 111, at least 15 hours in mathematics courses that satisfy requirements for the Major in Mathematics, Physics 201, and Chemistry 121 .(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EGR 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the 196| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 preparation of a formal paper.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

e: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG-English ENG 101 - English Composition for Second Language Learners (3) A semester-length course for second language learners of English whose writing skills, as determined through standardized tests and/or writing samples, need additional practice to reach college-level proficiency in writing for academic courses.(3 credit hours).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 109 - Enhanced Skills in Writing (1) This course, for which ENG 110 is a co-requisite, builds students' skills in engaged reading, critical thinking, essay organization and development, and grammar, with particular attention to editing and revision in regard to style and clarity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students revise personal and persuasive essays and speeches from Eng.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+110, focusing on grammar and structure vital to clear writing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

m Eng.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+110, focusing on grammar and structure vital to clear writing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The semester grade will be S/U; a student earning a U will have that grade recorded on the transcript but will not be required to repeat the course.(1 credit hour) Prerequisite: Placement into the course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: ENG 110.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 110 - Composition and Speech I (3) This course develops students' skills in communicating clearly through writing and speech, with attention to all stages of the composing process, including analysis of the rhetorical situation, invention and drafting, choices of evidence, peer conferencing, and revision.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students complete a variety of essays and presentations, with emphasis on persuasion and basic research.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into the course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ours) Prerequisite: Placement into the course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 120 - Composition and Speech II (3) This course hones students' skills in writing and speech, with particular emphasis on strategies and sources appropriate for academic and professional work.It also provides instruction in argumentation and library research that supports students' completion of an extended researched argument as well as multiple shorter writing assignments and presentations.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 110 or placement into the course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer, May Term.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 121 - Syntax for Writing (1) This course continues development of writing skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+It includes instruction on how to use the phrasal and clausal structures most common in English to craft grammatically correct sentences in paragraphs that show good variety of sentence openers, sentence structure, and sentence length.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

that show good variety of sentence openers, sentence structure, and sentence length.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Open to all students, it is required of students who have earned a grade of U on the English Proficiency Exam.The course culminates in an administration of the proficiency exam.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1 credit hour) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 149 - Selected Topics in English (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 150 - Oral Rhetoric (3) This course enhances students' communications skills through direct instruction and practice in all stages of speech composition and delivery.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students make presentations for a variety of academic, professional, and community contexts, with emphasis on extemporaneous delivery.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

mic, professional, and community contexts, with emphasis on extemporaneous delivery.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Instructional points include relationship of oral and written style, audience analysis, organizational strategies, verbal citation of sources, and creation and integration of presentation aids.Small- group conferences and collaborative projects provide additional opportunities for honing skills in clear communication.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 160 - The Early Western Literary Tradition (3) A thematic approach designed to deepen understanding of the breadth, diversity and richness of Western culture as well as to develop interpretive and critical skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Readings include classical, medieval and Renaissance texts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course fulfills the core requirement in literature.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 170 - The Modern Western Literary Tradition (3) A thematic approach designed to deepen understanding of the breadth, diversity and richness of Western culture as Courses| 197 well as to develop interpretive and critical skills.Readings include neoclassical, romantic, modern and post-modern texts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course fulfills the core requirement in literature.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 180 - Literature and the American Experience (3) Encompassing diverse perspectives on the American experience expressed through a variety of literary genres, this course introduces the basic tools of literary interpretation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

rerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 181 - Women's and Multicultural Literature (3) Through a survey of women's and multicultural literature in the United States, this course introduces the basic tools of literary interpretation with a focus on gender and power structures.The reading list presents a variety of genres and a diversity of voices.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course fulfills core requirements in both Literary Studies and U.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+S.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Pluralism (3 credit hours).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, May Term.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 182 - Literature and the Classical Tradition (3) Designed to offer students an opportunity to improve their cultural literacy while honing their interpretive and critical skills, this course offers a close analysis of classical works in various genres and examines the influence this literature has had on the intellectual, psychological, and philosophical progress of Western civilization.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

the intellectual, psychological, and philosophical progress of Western civilization.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ This course fulfills the core requirement in literature.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 110 or higher.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 191 - American Literature: Puritan through Romantic (3) An examination of the literary expressions of culture in America from the early Puritans through the Civil War.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Special attention is paid to the coming of age of American literature in the mid-nineteenth century, with emphasis on the concept of self, transcendentalism, the frontier, and the meaning of symbol.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 196 - Survey of British Literature I (3) A study of works by major British authors, ranging from the Old English period through the eighteenth century.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

British authors, ranging from the Old English period through the eighteenth century.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ By providing an overview of the development of the British literary tradition, the course will enable students to situate works studied in advanced and period- specific courses within a broad context.Authors to be studied may include Chaucer, Langland, Spenser, Shakespeare, Milton, Dryden, Swift, Pope, and Johnson.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 201 - Advanced Literary Interpretation (3) A close analysis of modern fantasy with attention paid to the formal structures of the genre and its roots in the romance tradition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The emphasis is on such writers as J.R.R.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Tolkien, C.S.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Lewis, Ursula Le Guin, and Isaac Asimov.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 208 - Modern Fantasy and Science Fiction (3) A close analysis of modern fantasy with attention paid to the formal structures of the genre and its roots in the romance tradition.The emphasis is on such writers as J.R.R.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Tolkien, C.S.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Lewis, Ursula Le Guin, and Isaac Asimov.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 211 - Young Adult Literature (3) An introduction to the multiple genres of young adult literature.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course examines the historical development of literature written for and about young adults; develops an awareness of issues surrounding the use and teaching of young adult literature; and explores instructional strategies for incorporating young adult literature in the classroom.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Literary excellence in young adult literature, and current issues and controversies in the field will be discussed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ult literature, and current issues and controversies in the field will be discussed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Possible topics include Coming of Age Novels, the Multicultural Experience in Adolescent Literature, and Fantasy and Science Fiction.Course topics may change with each offering.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 212 - Children's Literature (3) An introduction to children's literature, with attention devoted to picture books, including fiction and nonfiction, poetry, and non-print materials.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Specific topics discussed 198| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 include literary styles, genres, the relationship of art and text, historical development of literature for children, the role of culturally diverse literature in the classroom, and criteria for evaluating contemporary literature.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course will explore ways to use literature to create engaging classroom experiences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 213 - Creative Writing: Poetry (3) Students write poetry, including assignments on specific topics and poetic forms.Class work includes practice in- group critiques, discussion of assigned works, and oral presentation of students' poetry.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 214 - Creative Writing: Fiction (3) Students write short fiction, including one critical/analytical essay/oral report on a fiction writer of each student's choosing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The class includes writing exercises, in-class group critiques of student work, discussion of assigned works, and individual conferences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course culminates in a class presentation/reading of revised, selected fiction.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 216 - Publications (1) Students work as staff members on The Highland Echo or Impressions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

Publications (1) Students work as staff members on The Highland Echo or Impressions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ This course can be taken for a maximum of four credit hours, at one credit per semester of service.This course is offered on an S/U basis only.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1 credit hour) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 217 - Journalism (3) An introduction to writing and editing for the print media, including focus on reporting and writing, as well as on editing, layout and design.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 219 - Advanced Rhetoric and Grammar (3) A course in rhetoric and writing conventions based on a study of grammar and syntax.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course is designed to provide the student with rhetorical options based on an understanding of the function of sentence parts in their relation to one another and to meaning.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 249 - Selected Topics in English (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 292 - American Literature: Realism to the Present (3) An examination of the literary expressions of culture in America from Reconstruction through the 20th century, emphasizing shifting definitions of America and conflict within American culture over that time period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 297 - Survey of British Literature II (3) A study of works by major British authors, ranging from the romantic period through the postmodern.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s by major British authors, ranging from the romantic period through the postmodern.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ By providing an overview of the development of British literary tradition, the course will enable students to situate works studied in advanced and period-specific courses within a broad context.Authors to be studied may include Blake, Austen, Wordsworth, the Brontes, Woolf, Yeats, Joyce, and Lessing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 120 or equivalent placement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 311 - History of the English Language (3) The history and development of the English language based on textual analysis of Old, Middle, and Early Modern English.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 312 - Linguistic Theory and Second Language Acquisition (3) Basic principles of linguistics, especially those pertaining to second language acquisition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

inciples of linguistics, especially those pertaining to second language acquisition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ A survey of the components of language such as syntax, semantics, morphology and phonology, and all major subfields of linguistics such as psycholinguistics and neurolinguistics.Studying relationships among psychological, social, and cultural issues that impact second language acquisition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 219.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Courses| 199 ENG 313 - Advanced Creative Writing: Poetry (3) In this course, students will engage with poetry as a profession and a craft.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+An intensive workshop setting will encourage inquiry and practice of advanced techniques within the realm of content, form, rhythm, and style.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Some lecture about prosody and discussion about respected poetry will supplement this practice, as well as the introduction to methodologies and experiences in the literary publishing world and the Master of Fine Arts degree.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

and experiences in the literary publishing world and the Master of Fine Arts degree.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 213 or permission of instructor.Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 314 - Creative Nonfiction (3) An advanced study of a large body of peer and professional writing that builds upon requisite critical skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will produce fact-based creative writing, including one major critical/analytical essay/oral report on a write of choice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Class will include writing exercises, in- class group critiques of student work, discussion of assigned works and individual conferences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: One course from ENG 213, ENG 214, or ENG 217 and Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 315 - Business and Technical Writing (3) The study and practice of formats for business, scientific, and technical writing used in corporate and government contexts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

siness, scientific, and technical writing used in corporate and government contexts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Practice in information gathering, writing, editing, and speaking is emphasized in both individual and group work.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 316 - Advanced Creative Writing: Fiction (3) In this class students will read and analyze literary fiction and compose their own fiction through a drafting process.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Each of their fictional works will be critiqued in an advanced workshop setting that will require students to practice written and oral techniques of constructive criticism.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+We will also address outlets for publication of literary fiction--journals and book publishers--and discuss preparation for and standards of graduate programs in creative writing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 213 or ENG 214, or permission of instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

te: ENG 213 or ENG 214, or permission of instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 317 - Public Relations Writing and Practice (3) An introduction to a variety of public relations writing styles, including copy for newsletters, brochures, news releases, and speeches.Lecture/discussion sessions provide an overview of public relations principles and theory.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course builds toward a public relations campaign as the major final project.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 322 - Advanced Studies in American Literature (3) The course examines selected authors, periods and/or genres for thematic, formal, historical, and cultural issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Course content and focus will vary.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 331 - Chaucer in Middle English (3) Major works of Chaucer read in Middle English, with lectures on the historical and literary backgrounds.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

er read in Middle English, with lectures on the historical and literary backgrounds.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 332 - Shakespeare (3) A study of Shakespeare's plays, with equal emphasis on the comedies, tragedies, and histories as well as attention to the literary and historical backgrounds of the period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 333 - English Literature of the 17th Century (3) A study of the poetry, drama, and prose of the 17th century to the Restoration, focusing on major themes and literary developments in their historical contexts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Special emphasis will be placed on interpretive methods as they apply to some of the major texts of the period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 191, ENG 292, ENG 196, or ENG 297; or junior standing and completion of one 100-level (or higher) literature course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

f one 100-level (or higher) literature course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENG 334 - English Literature of the Restoration and 18th Century (3) A study of the poetry, drama, and prose of the "long" 18th century (1660-1815), focusing on major themes and literary developments in their historical contexts.Special emphasis will be placed on interpretive methods as they apply to some of the major texts of the period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 191, ENG 292, ENG 196, or ENG 297; or junior standing and completion of one 100-level (or 200| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 higher) literature course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 335 - English Literature of the 19th Century (3) A study of the poetry and non-fiction prose of the English Romantic and Victorian periods, focusing on major themes in the respective historical periods.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Special emphasis will be placed on interpretive methods as they apply to some of the major texts of the period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

aced on interpretive methods as they apply to some of the major texts of the period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Prerequisite: ENG 191, ENG 292, ENG 196, or ENG 297; or junior standing and completion of one 100-level (or higher) literature course.Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 336 - British and American Literature of the 20th Century (3) A study of selected 20th century British and American authors using multiple interpretive methods.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphases will include building an understanding of some of the larger literary and theoretical movements of the 20th century through extensive reading of literature and criticism.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 191, ENG 292, ENG 196, or ENG 297; or junior standing and completion of one 100-level (or higher) literature course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 337 - Internship (0-15) Field experience that provides an introduction to careers in writing and communications through work on the writing staff of a newspaper, magazine, publishing house, or related enterprise.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ See Course Description in Highlander Hub.Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing, and HUM 347.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 352 - Senior Study II (3) Eng.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+352 is the second course in the two-course sequence fulfilling the Senior Study requirement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study with the guidance of a faculty supervisor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

t provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a formal paper.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.ENG 399 - Writing Communication Capstone (3) This course will prepare students for the job market and/or graduate-level study through production of a portfolio and submission of select pieces for publication.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Additionally, the course will focus on publishing, job search, and interview practice; discernment of vocation and employment through readings and class visits from alumni; and presentation and defense of the senior study.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will personalize their portfolio materials depending on their interest and skill set gained from internships.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course will culminate in the thesis presentation/defense and Courses| 201 portfolio submission, which will include reflective essays covering courses taken in the major.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: English 351.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

urses taken in the major.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: English 351.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 337.Corequisite: Pre- or co-requisite: ENG 337.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV-Environmental Studies ENV 101 - Environmental Issues and Foundations of Sustainability (3) An introduction to the origins and interrelationships of major contemporary environmental issues, such as global climate change, sustainable development, population, ozone depletion, deforestation, energy, and water pollution.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course examines the complexity of the issues in environmental, political, social, and economic terms.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This interdisciplinary course will use sustainability concepts, theories, and applications as avenues for approaching and practicing various ways of viewing our planet.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 149 - Selected Topics in Environmental Studies (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 231 - Environmental Sociology (3) The study of the relationship between human societies and their physical environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Course focuses on how environmental sociologists explain the origins of environmental degradation, how environmental harms are unequally distributed among different communities and nations, and the role that social movements play in addressing these issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 249 - Selected Topics in Environmental Studies (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ENV 337 - Internship in Environmental Studies (0-15) Field experiences that provide practical applications in appropriate work settings.For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing and permission of the Division of Social Sciences Chair.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 345 - Environmental Politics (3) A study of the political history, stakeholders, and topical issues related to American and global environmental policymaking.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Comparison of environmentalism (conservation, sustainable development, deep ecology).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Investigation of structure and actors making environmental policy.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Survey of current global/eco-systemic issues in environmental policy (air, sea/water, energy and waste, land).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

co-systemic issues in environmental policy (air, sea/water, energy and waste, land).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Special emphasis on Tennessee and East Tennessee issues, such as acid rain in the Great Smoky Mountains, Tennessee Valley energy development, and water management in conflict with the snail darter.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 346 - Environmental Economics (3) A broad introduction to the field of environmental and ecological economics exploring the relationship between the economy and the environment and how economic theory can be used to study and address environmental issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include criteria for setting standards, selecting economic regulatory tools, and designing policy.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ECN 201.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENV 349 - Selected Topics in Environmental Studies (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

e: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ ESL-English as a Second Language ESL 101 - Introductory English I (3) An introduction to the beginning structures of English as a Second Language using concepts related to people, places and objects within the immediate environment.Emphasis is also given to communicating in beginning English within well-defined contexts, developing basic vocabulary, and writing simple sentences in English.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+A whole language approach of reading, writing, listening and speaking incorporates appropriate grammar structures and develops receptive and productive skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) ESL 102 - Introductory English II (3) A sequel to the beginning structures of English as a Second Language using concepts related to people, places and objects within the immediate environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is also given to communicating in beginning English with the addition of the simple past tense, expanding basic vocabulary, and writing simple sentences in English.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

vocabulary, writing academic essay structures in English, and giving presentations.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ A whole language approach of reading, writing, listening and speaking incorporates appropriate grammar structures and develops receptive and productive skills.(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+204| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 ETH-Ethics ETH 490 - Philosophical and Theological Foundations of Ethical Thought (3) A senior capstone, interdisciplinary course which considers the ethical dimension of the human experience, including historic and contemporary ethical frameworks designed to engage the students' ethical stances.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students reflect on general education, major courses of study and chosen vocation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Special concern to address service, global citizenship, and responsibility for the common good.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Senior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, May Term, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

erequisite: Senior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, May Term, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EVS-Environmental Science EVS 111 - Fundamentals of Earth System Science (4) An introduction to the Earth system and the solid Earth, atmosphere, oceans, and biosphere.Topics include: global change in modern environments and ancient analogues; an introduction to oceanography and atmospheric science; the carbon cycle; the solid Earth; diversity of biospheric interactions; long-term climate regulation; and human threats to the environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Intended for students not majoring in the Natural Sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: MTH 110.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 112 - Fundamentals of Environmental Science (4) The course is intended for non-science majors.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course provides students with a basic understanding of major principles and unifying concepts within Environmental Science.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

nderstanding of major principles and unifying concepts within Environmental Science.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Topics include: humans and sustainability; science and ecological principles; sustaining biodiversity and natural resources; and sustaining environmental quality and human societies.Students will gain an awareness of the importance of Earth's systems in sustaining our daily lives, plus the scientific foundation and tools needed to apply critical thought to contemporary environmental issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: MTH 110.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 117 - Introduction to Environmental Science (4) Introduction to physical and ecological principles, concepts, and methodologies that serve as the foundation of environmental systems and strategies for sustainable management of the earth's ecosystems.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Laboratory work supplements and expands lecture topics as well as introduces techniques used by Environmental Scientists.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ds lecture topics as well as introduces techniques used by Environmental Scientists.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Intended for students majoring or minoring in Environmental Science and for non-majors who want or need a more challenging introductory course in biology.(4 credit hours) EVS 149 - Selected Topics in Environmental Science (1- 4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 201 - Earth System Processes (4) This course and accompanying lab will focus on the characteristics and processes of the Earth’s surface and lower atmosphere.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include: climate, earth materials, tectonic activity, geomorphic processes and landforms, soils, and human impacts on the landscape.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: A C- or higher in BIO 111, EVS 117, or BIO 113, and sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

rerequisite: A C- or higher in BIO 111, EVS 117, or BIO 113, and sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EVS 249 - Selected Topics in Environmental Science (1- 4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 310 - Earth System Science (4) This course and accompanying lab will focus on the interplay among the individual components of the Earth system â€" the solid Earth, atmosphere, oceans, and biosphere.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include: global change in modern environments and ancient analogues; an introduction to oceanography and atmospheric science; the carbon cycle; the solid Earth; diversity of biospheric interactions; long- term climate regulation; and human threats to the environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: (1) A grade of C- or higher in BIO 221 and BIO 222; or (2) CHM 121 and a grade of C- or higher in BIO 115 and BIO 222.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

221 and BIO 222; or (2) CHM 121 and a grade of C- or higher in BIO 115 and BIO 222.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EVS 311 - Natural History of the Great Smoky Mountains (4) An investigation of the landforms, flora, and fauna of the Southern Appalachians, especially as found in the Great Smoky Mountains.Topics include: relationships between climate, geology, and topographic features; recognition of Courses| 205 common biotic communities; identification of characteristic plants, animals, and fungi along with their habitats; roles played by plants, animals and fungi within communities; and impact of human activity on ecosystems in the region.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Laboratory exercises incorporate field work in the Maryville College woods and local points of interest, including the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: A grade of C- or higher in BIO 113.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s) Prerequisite: A grade of C- or higher in BIO 113.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EVS 337 - Internship in Environmental Science (0-15) Practical on-campus or off-campus experiences that apply methodologies and techniques of environmental science in actual work settings in academic institutions, government laboratories or agencies, or private companies and organizations.For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: At least 2.8 GPA in major/related courses, sophomore, junior, or senior standing and division approval.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 349 - Selected Topics in Environmental Science (1- 4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

equisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EVS 351 - Senior Study I (3) EVS351 is the first semester in a two-course sequence that satisfies the Senior Study requirement for BS degrees in the Natural Sciences.Guided by a faculty mentor, students develop a research project, initiate feasibility studies, and report findings in a format appropriate for the field and specific project.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120, English Proficiency Exam, and junior standing, at least 16 hours in Biology, Chemistry, and Environmental Science courses that satisfy the requirements for a major in Environmental Science.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 352 - Senior Study II (3) EVS352 is the second semester in a two-course sequence that satisfies the Senior Study requirement for BS degrees in the Natural Sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

that satisfies the Senior Study requirement for BS degrees in the Natural Sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Guided by a faculty mentor, students perform experiments proposed in EVS 351, collect and analyze their data, and report findings in a format appropriate for the field and specific project.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EVS351.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EVS 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a formal paper.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS-Exercise Science EXS 149 - Selected Topics in Exercise Science (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ See Course Description in Highlander Hub.Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 217 - Human Anatomy and Physiology I (4) A survey of the structure and function of the human integumentary, nervous, skeletal, and muscular systems.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+An introduction to cells and tissues is included.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Laboratory work involves examination of models, mammalian dissections, and the study of skeletons.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 218 - Human Anatomy and Physiology II (4) A survey of the structure and function of the human digestive, respiratory, circulatory, immune, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems in humans.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Laboratory work involves examination of models, mammalian dissections, and measurement of physiological processes.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 217 or BIO 217.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 217 or BIO 217.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EXS 219 - Principles of Human Nutrition (3) Focus is on optimal nutrition for energy, growth and health.The course includes information regarding the functions and interactions of vitamins, minerals and nutrients.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Assessments, analysis and appropriate interventions are addressed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+206| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 EXS 221 - Nutrition Across the Lifespan (3) Examination of changes in nutrient needs that accompany growth and development from the prenatal stage through old age.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis will be on high-risk groups and current issues affecting people at various stages of the life cycle.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 219.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 219.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EXS 222 - Sport and Exercise Nutrition (3) Explores the fundamental biochemical and physiological rationale for optimal nutrient intake for health, physical fitness, and athletic performance.Specifically, attention will focus on the relationship between nutrition and exercise, physical fitness, health, and athletic performance.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 219.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 241 - Population Health and Disease Prevention (3) This course will discuss causes of disease throughout the lifespan and interventions designed to prevent disease.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Basic principles and methods used in epidemiology will be introduced.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PHR 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 242 - Physical Activity and Chronic Disease (3) This course examines the interaction of physical activity with pathophysiology and with the treatment of chronic diseases and conditions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

vity with pathophysiology and with the treatment of chronic diseases and conditions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 241.Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 249 - Selected Topics in Exercise Science (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 311 - Athletic Training (3) Prerequisite: EXS 217, EXS 218, and American Red Cross certifications in Standard First Aid and CPR.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: EXS 217, EXS 218, and American Red Cross certifications in Standard First Aid and CPR.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 312 - Advanced Athletic Training (3) This course is designed for the student with plans to pursue a career in sports medicine.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

course is designed for the student with plans to pursue a career in sports medicine.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ It covers advanced techniques in first aid, therapeutic exercise and modalities, clinical evaluations, and ethical and legal responsibilities of an athletic trainer.Laboratory experience includes working with the intercollegiate men's and women's athletic teams and experience in a local sports medicine facility.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 311.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 332 - Kinesiology (3) A study of human movement from anatomical and mechanical perspectives to include equilibrium, force, motion, leverage and fluid mechanics.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 217 and EXS 218.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 337 - Internship in Exercise Science (0-15) Field experiences that provide practical applications in appropriate work settings.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

nted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing and two exercise science courses at the 300-level, or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 342 - Research Methods in Physical Activity (3) Introduction to fundamental principles underlying research methods in exercise science.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Included will be basic procedures for conducting experimental, descriptive, historical, qualitative research, computer applications, basic measurement concepts, statistical methods, critical thinking, and scholarly writing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: STA 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 345 - Physiology of Exercise (3) Study of the physiological principles related to exercise and human movement to include health and sport related components of physical fitness.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

d human movement to include health and sport related components of physical fitness.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 217 and EXS 218.Offered: Fall, Spring, May Term, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 349 - Selected Topics in Exercise Science (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Courses| 207 EXS 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, EXS 342, and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

cy Exam, EXS 342, and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ EXS 352 - Senior Study II (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 352 is the second course.The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Ordinarily taken in the fall term of the senior year and preceded by 351 in the spring term of the junior year.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: EXS 351, ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, EXS 342, and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

perience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.EXS 365 - Pediatric Exercise Physiology (3) Physiological responses to exercise, methodologies for assessing physical fitness and physical activity, and promotion of physical activity in children and adolescents will be discussed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Current research in various topics related to exercise in children and adolescents will be explored.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 345.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 399 - Building Healthy Communities (3) This capstone course will examine societal challenges and solutions that affect communities across the nation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+We will discuss concepts related to physical activity promotion, healthy nutrition, and mental health behaviors, along with broader topics concerning a sense of purpose, belonging, and integration within larger communities.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

concerning a sense of purpose, belonging, and integration within larger communities.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Additionally, the course will cover discussions on Appalachian health, health disparities, access challenges, and environmental sustainability.Students will engage in experiential learning by conducting a community needs assessment and developing evidence-based programs.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+In addition, students will reflect on their personal health practices and create a personalized health ethic, fostering lifelong well-being.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior or senior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 411 - Exercise Testing and Prescription (3) Theory and practice of exercise prescription for healthy individuals, cardiac patients, and other special populations according to the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

populations according to the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Assessment and application of the various aspects of exercise testing such as the assessment of risk stratification, cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength and endurance, body composition, and flexibility for both a general health and fitness population and a clinical population.The American College of Sports Medicine's Guidelines for Exercise Testing and Prescription will be emphasized with specific focus on the knowledge, skills, and abilities for obtaining the Health Fitness Specialist (HFS) certification.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: EXS 345.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+EXS 412 - Biomechanical Principles of Human Movement (3) The principles of classical mechanics are applied to the study of human motion to provide students with an understanding of the internal and external forces acting on the body during human movement.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The role of muscle in generating force and controlling movement is emphasized.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

\!)\s+The role of muscle in generating force and controlling movement is emphasized.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: MTH 115 and EXS 332.FRM-Fermentation FRM 101 - Introduction to Fermentation Sciences (3) This course is a survey of different areas of chemistry and how they relate to beer and the brewing industry.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+It covers the chemical and biochemical processes that are involved in fermentation, with a focus on the brewing of beer, as well as a study of how analytical techniques are used in modern brewing industry.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course also addresses the 208| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 physiology and history of alcohol consumption.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into MTH 112 or above, or successful completion of MTH 105.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+FRM 201 - Principles of Brewing Science (4) This course covers the processes of brewing beer from the homebrew scale up to the pilot brewery scale.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The topics build on the information taught in FRM 101 with hands on experience in the lab.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

pics build on the information taught in FRM 101 with hands on experience in the lab.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The lecture portion of the course focuses on recipe creation, brewing operations, and product analysis and quality control while the lab portion of the course applies these concepts.(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: FRM 101 and must be 21 or older.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+FRM 337 - Internship in Fermentation Sciences (3) Practical on-campus or off-campus experiences that apply methodologies and techniques of the fermentation sciences in actual work settings in academic institutions, government laboratories or agencies, or private companies and organizations.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ty.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) FRN-French FRN 110 - Elementary French I (4) An introduction to French designed to give students the linguistic, cultural, and geographical background necessary to provide for their basic needs when they travel to a French- speaking country.Emphasis is also given to conversing in basic French within well-defined contexts, to reading short passages, and to writing simple sentences in French.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Cultural concepts, grammatical structures, and vocabulary introduced in class are reinforced in small- group language practice sessions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+FRN 120 - Elementary French II (4) A sequel to French 110, designed to increase knowledge of the basic language, culture, and geography of the Francophone world.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is also given to increasing students' capacity to converse, read, and write in French.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+
