Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ PSY 211 - Child Development (3) This course focuses on the development of the child, perinatally to pre-adolescence.Physical, cognitive, social, and emotional domains are related to various stages of development.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Key environmental contexts, including child poverty, trauma, and adversity, are examined.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 218 - Adolescent Development (3) This course focuses on the development of the adolescent from puberty through emerging adulthood.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The interplay of physical, cognitive, social, and emotional domains is examined through the various stages of development.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Key environmental contexts, including families, peer relationships, schools, and youth organizations will be discussed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

be discussed.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+238| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 PSY 221 - Social Psychology (3) Examination of ways in which human affect, cognition, and behavior are influenced by other individuals or groups.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Impression management, self concept, attitudes, persuasion, attraction, helping behavior, aggression, stereotyping and prejudice, and conformity are among the topics studied.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 222 - Adult Development and Aging (3) Development of adults from young adulthood through the rest of the lifespan.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Psychological, cognitive, social, emotional, and physical aspects of aging are considered as they relate to adult development.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Field observation of older adults is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

of older adults is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring.PSY 224 - Cross-Cultural Psychology (3) A selection of the theoretical, empirical, and applied issues in cross-cultural study of human behavior that examines how and why behavior differs across cultures.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Understanding of culture, cultural differences, and the ways that sociocultural context influences the thinking and social behavior of individuals.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is placed on empirical methods in cross-cultural psychology to achieve an appreciation of cultural groups both within and outside the United States.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 226 - Global Child Welfare (3) Global Child Welfare examines the history of children’s rights and the study of international standards and monitoring systems.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

f children’s rights and the study of international standards and monitoring systems.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Drawing from neuroscientific, psychological, sociological, and international studies perspectives, students study the effects of interpersonal violence, health, justice, community violence, civil war, education, trauma, and resilience on children.This course usually has a travel abroad component.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Permission by instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 227 - Intimate Relationships (3) An integral part of the human experience is the ability to create and maintain interpersonal relationships.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Intimate relationships with family, friends, and romantic others, are associated with academic performance, health, and general well-being.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Understanding psychological, societal, and cultural factors that influence relationship expectations can help us achieve more meaningful relationships.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

fluence relationship expectations can help us achieve more meaningful relationships.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Topics covered include: attraction, communication, love, sexuality, loss of relationships, and maintenance of relationships.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Person & Society (PS) core requirement and sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 228 - Human Sexuality (3) Human Sexuality provides a comprehensive introduction to the psychobiological, psychosocial, behavioral, and cross-cultural aspects of sexuality.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Theoretical and empirical research will be utilized to better understand the broad range of attitudes, behaviors, knowledge, practices, and myths pertaining to sexuality.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include, but are not limited to, gender development, sexual orientation, contraception, sexually transmitted diseases, sexual problems, sexual disorders, and therapies.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Person & Society (PS) core requirement and sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

re requirement and sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ PSY 232 - Child Trauma and Resilience (3) Students will develop a foundation for understanding childhood trauma, post-trauma responses, and approaches to working with children experiencing trauma and stress.The course examines the relationship between trauma and physiological disorders and look at trauma within various contexts, such as home, school, and community.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+It also reviews related issues, including bereavement, mental health, recovery and resilience.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Ways in which teachers, therapists, and other caregivers work with traumatized populations will be explored.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement with either at-risk populations or programs that support trauma- informed practices is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 244 - Introduction to Neuroscience (3) An introduction to the biological bases of behavior.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ntroduction to Neuroscience (3) An introduction to the biological bases of behavior.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Fundamentals of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neurotransmission will be covered.Other topics include psychoactive drugs, stress, sleep, hunger, sexual behavior, memory, biological basis of psychological disorders, and neurological disorders.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 248 - Drugs and Behavior (3) Study of psychoactive drugs and their effects on brain and behavior.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include basic psychopharmacology, therapeutic and non-therapeutic psychoactive drugs, and related issues of substance abuse and impact on society and public policy.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Courses| 239 Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1-4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1-4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ See Course Description in Highlander Hub.Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer, May Term.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 289 - Psychology of Language and Communication (3) Combining theory and practice, this course is designed to develop knowledge and skills for communicating in personal and professional contexts.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Through lectures, readings, discussion, and individual and group work, students will gain greater understanding of language and communication theory from psychology and related fields.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course will cover a range of topics related to communication and language, such as social and cultural influences on communication, digitally mediated communication, communication in groups, and nonverbal communication.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+In addition to opportunities to further develop analytical and critical thinking skills, students will refine communication skills through individual and group projects.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ls, students will refine communication skills through individual and group projects.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and Sophomore standing.Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 299 - Contemporary and Professional Issues in Psychology (2) A course for new majors to examine contemporary and professional issues in Psychology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will explore their professional goals and practice foundational skills essential throughout the field of psychology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Essential for ethical psychological practices as defined by the American Psychological Association (APA), students will develop knowledge, awareness, reflective practice, and skills needed to promote health, well-being, and equity for racially and ethnically diverse individuals and communities.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will also practice networking and applying their field of study to real world topics.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

world topics.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (2 credit hours) Prerequisite: Major in Psychology, Psychology with Counseling Track, Neuroscience, or Developmental Psychology and PSY 101.Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 301 - Theories of Personality (3) An examination of the major theoretical approaches to personality and their application in the field of psychology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Personality tests and their interpretation and connection to theory are also examined.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 311 - Research Design (3) This course will build on students’ understanding of basic research design.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+In this course, emphasis is on ethics in research, foundations of empirical literacy, measurement creation, and research protocol formulation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will complete an APA style research proposal.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and STA 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

esearch proposal.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and STA 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring.PSY 312 - Experimental Psychology (4) Methodological approach to psychological investigation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course concentrates on research practicum, analysis, and dissemination with an emphasis on statistical methodology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will conduct a student-led research project and complete a research report and presentation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Completion of PSY 311 with a grade of C- minus or better.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 314 - Cognitive Psychology (4) Examination of theories and research in cognition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Explores nature of human thought processes including topics on perception, attention, memory, language, problem-solving, and reasoning.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Laboratory practice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and PSY 312.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

it hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and PSY 312.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ PSY 315 - Human Thought and Learning (4) The main foci of this course are the foundational and contemporary research studies that have contributed to the various approaches to learning (Behavioral, Cognitive, Social Learning, Humanistic, and Neurological) and how these approaches can be applied to enhance one's own learning as well as to facilitate the learning of others.Topics include but are not limited to: classical conditioning, operant conditioning, information processing, triadic reciprocal causation, modeling, self- efficacy, motivation, attribution, and self-actualization.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The lab component of this course will further students research and statistical skills and will require human subjects' experimentation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Prerequisite: PSY 101, STA 120, and junior standing; Pre 240| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 or co-requisite: PSY 299.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre or co-requisite: PSY 299.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

or co-requisite: PSY 299.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: Pre or co-requisite: PSY 299.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.PSY 324 - Child Poverty and Inequality (3) The study of the developmental effects of childhood poverty and inequality on children's physical and mental health, school achievement, and safety.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Various social contexts will be explored, including housing, medical, education, and justice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Community engagement is a key component of this course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 327 - Sensation and Perception (4) An examination of the physiological and psychological bases of sensation and perception.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include color vision, perception of movement, size and distance, pitch perception, taste, and touch.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Includes lectures, discussion, in-class demonstration, and laboratory practice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ PSY 331 - Abnormal Psychology (3) A psychological approach to the causes, symptoms, treatment, and prevention of abnormal behavior.Attention to the various perspectives of abnormal behavior, assessment and classification.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 333 - Theories and Techniques in Counseling (3) Examination of the major theories and techniques of counseling, ethical decision-making, and diversity issues that counselors must consider.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 336 - Community Psychology and Social Justice (3) Students will examine research and theory on the ways that individuals relate to their communities as well as the reciprocal effect of communities on individuals.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

to their communities as well as the reciprocal effect of communities on individuals.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will learn how research findings from psychology can be used to promote positive change, health, and empowerment at individual and systemic levels, decreasing human suffering and promoting values of equality and justice.Even the field of psychology itself will be examined through the lens of social justice principles.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics may include social movements, stigma, power, privilege, oppression, sexism, racism, ableism, classism, heterosexism, and economic justice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Course will include project-based learning.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101 and Junior Standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 337 - Internship in Psychology (0-15) Supervised field experiences that provide practical applications in appropriate work settings.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ding and permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ PSY 338 - Introduction to Counseling Practice (3) An introduction to the foundations of the professional practice of counseling/psychotherapy including self- reflection, self-care, and basic listening skills.The course will include a didactic portion as well as student case presentations and group supervision.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 333.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 349 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1-4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Courses| 241 Proficiency Exam, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 352 - Senior Study II (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 352 is the second course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Ordinarily taken in the fall term of the senior year and preceded by 351 in the spring term of the junior year.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: PSY 351.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

|\?|\!)\s+ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer, May Term.PSY 353 - Senior Study (3) Under the guidance of a faculty member, students will complete a senior study project that begins with self- directed exploration of foundational research and theory in the discipline related to a topic of their choice.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The project will facilitate discovery, creativity, and engagement within the student’s major field through a scaffolded, iterative process.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will have the opportunity to take initiative, plan and execute substantial work, and experience the confidence and pride of accomplishment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+In addition, the course will include development of professional skills and will culminate in formal presentation of the projects.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+A final reflective component will allow students to articulate the purpose and significance of the project personally and professionally and connect it to their major and core courses.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

roject personally and professionally and connect it to their major and core courses.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 311 and senior standing.Corequisite: MCW 400.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 401 - History and Systems of Psychology (3) History of psychological thought from ancient Greek philosophers to twenty-first century psychologists is explored.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The emergence of the various systems and their comparison on classical problems are also examined.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Analysis of primary source material is a key feature of the course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing and 12 credit hours in Psychology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+PSY 402 - Advanced Neuroscience (3) Advanced study of topics in neuroscience.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course will build upon topics covered in the Introduction to Neuroscience and focus on Neuropsychology and Neurocognition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101, PSY 244, and BIO 113 or BIO 115.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1-4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ See Course Description in Highlander Hub.Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer, May Term.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 149 - American Christianities (3) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 162 - Approaches to the Study of Religion (3) An introduction to various modes of inquiry in the study of religion including theology, philosophy of religion, textual studies, and comparative religion.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 209 - Religion in the Southern Appalachians (3) A study of Appalachian mountain religion in its historical and cultural context.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

(3) A study of Appalachian mountain religion in its historical and cultural context.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Appalachian denominations are examined to determine how they have developed into 242| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 distinct forms of American Protestantism by analyzing southern Appalachian religious music, preaching rhetoric, and worship practices.(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 211 - The American Religious Experience (3) Experience (3) An introduction to religious studies which employs the American religious experience as its model.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 212 - World Religions (3) Religion as a universal human phenomenon.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Each offering of the course will examine several religious traditions such as Islam, Judaism, Hinduism, Taoism, Buddhism, and Christianity, as well as indigenous religions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Sophomore standing or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

nding or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ REL 228 - Introduction to Christian Theology (3) An examination of reflective thinking on basic Christian beliefs and practices.No experience in theology is required.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 325 - Sociology of Religion (3) A study of religion and the social order.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Religion as an integral part of human culture, the building of a sacred cosmos.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Religion and social organization, civil religion, secularization, religion and social change, cross-cultural comparisons.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

site: SOC 101 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ REL 326 - Contemporary Theology (3) An examination of 20th century Christian thought, with special emphasis on current issues, approaches, and major thinkers.Attention is given to the social, political, and historical context of contemporary theology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Any religion course or junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 337 - Internship in Religion (0-15) An on- or off-campus experience that provides an introduction to careers in religion, enhances understanding of the role of religion in human culture, or applies knowledge gained through the study of religion.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: Permission of the Division Chair.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

isite: Any religion course or junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ REL 348 - Explorations in the History of Religions (3) Topics will vary.A study of one or more of the world's religious traditions or a comparative study of a theme or themes in more than one tradition.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Any religion course or junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+REL 349 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Courses| 243 REL 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing, HUM 347.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.REL 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SCI-Science SCI 299 - Professional Practices in the Natural Sciences (1) This course focuses on career preparation, professional practices in the natural sciences, and preparation for Senior Study.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Career preparation activities will include instruction and practice in skills needed to gain admission to graduate and professional schools and to find gainful employment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

gain admission to graduate and professional schools and to find gainful employment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Instruction on professional practices in science will include discussion of workplace culture and research ethics.Students will become familiar with Senior Study requirements and expectations.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1 credit hour) Prerequisite: CHM 122.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SLS-Social Sciences Interdisciplinary Courses SLS 203 - Introduction to Nonprofit Management (3) An examination of the basic principles and processes of nonprofit management.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics include board/committee development, recruitment, planning, marketing, risk management, budget management, fundraising and philanthropy.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SLS 299 - Issues in Professional Development (2) A course for new majors to examine contemporary and professional issues in the social sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

r new majors to examine contemporary and professional issues in the social sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will explore their vocational goals, including an investigation of options for the significant practical experience and senior study.The course will also provide a foundation in basic MLA and research skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Finally, each student will engage in activities that will enhance professional behaviors.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(2 credit hours) Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SLS 301 - Social Sciences Research Methods (3) The philosophy and methodology of the social sciences.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is on the philosophical underpinnings, basic research design, forms of data gathering and the analysis, presentation, and interpretation of data.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual and/or group research projects relate to various social science disciplines.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: STA 120 and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

equisite: STA 120 and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SOC-Sociology SOC 101 - Introductory Sociology (3) Study of the fundamental structure and dynamics of human societies and the basic principles and concepts used in sociology.(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 149 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+244| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 SOC 211 - Cultural Anthropology (3) An application of the concept of culture to various societies, from primitive to modern.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Cross-cultural analysis of various institutions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Extensive use of ethnographies.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

shaped by gender.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101 or GWS 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SOC 221 - Social Psychology (3) Examination of ways in which human affect, cognition, and behavior are influenced by other individuals or groups.Impression management, self concept, attitudes, persuasion, attraction, helping behavior, aggression, stereotyping and prejudice, and conformity are among the topics studied.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: PSY 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 222 - Sociology of Appalachia (3) To study the historical development of the Appalachian region from its early incorporation into the capitalist world system to the present day.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course examines the interplay of political- economic development and social constructions of the Appalachian region throughout the modern era.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

opment and social constructions of the Appalachian region throughout the modern era.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Social problems such as inequality, poverty, environmental degradation, absentee land ownership, and social movements will be addressed along with cultural analysis of the Appalachian region.(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 226 - Global Child Welfare (3) Global Child Welfare examines the history of children’s rights and the study of international standards and monitoring systems.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Drawing from neuroscientific, psychological, sociological, and international studies perspectives, students study the effects of interpersonal violence, health, justice, community violence, civil war, education, trauma, and resilience on children.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course usually has a travel abroad component.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Permission by instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 231 - Environmental Sociology (3) The study of the relationship between human societies and their physical environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

he study of the relationship between human societies and their physical environment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Course focuses on how environmental sociologists explain the origins of environmental degradation, how environmental harms are unequally distributed among different communities and nations, and the role that social movements play in addressing these issues.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 305 - Organizational Behavior (3) Analysis of complex organizations and bureaucracy.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The goals, design, internal structure, and environmental relations of organizations.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The focus is on the individual, the group and the organization as units of analysis.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

The focus is on the individual, the group and the organization as units of analysis.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101 and junior standing or permission of instructor.Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 315 - Social Inequality (3) Race, social class, and gender are systems of inequality that shape culture and society.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course explores how these inequalities affect the experience of diverse groups in society.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+We examine inequalities of race, class, and gender as they relate to social institutions and key contemporary social issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101 or permission of the instructor and junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 320 - Development and Globalization (3) Critical examination of development and social change in the modern world, emphasizing the inequities of our Courses| 245 current era of globalization and the myriad social issues facing the global community in the 21st century.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

zation and the myriad social issues facing the global community in the 21st century.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The course will include a review of major theories of development and their implications for future development trajectories.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 325 - Sociology of Religion (3) A study of religion and the social order.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Religion as an integral part of human culture, the building of a sacred cosmos.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Religion and social organization, civil religion, secularization, religion and social change, cross-cultural comparisons.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 326 - Social Movements (3) A study of social movements: their emergence, tactics, outcomes, and their participants.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Examines collective efforts to contest and alter the existing social order and dominant power arrangements.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

dominant power arrangements.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SOC 327 - Sociology of Culture (3) An examination of the concept of culture from a sociological perspective.Introduces different cultural explanations for social behavior, meaning-making, and social structure; examines the production, consumption, and reception of culture; and outlines cultural perspectives on diverse aspects of social life.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SOC 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 328 - Global Feminisms (3) For many people around the world, the word "feminism" is an ambiguous term and often carries a negative connotation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course is designed to enable students to understand the diverse forms of feminisms around the globe in relation to philosophical and political issues.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will study different types of feminism as they emerge from specific contexts and the impact of context on the articulation of feminist ideas.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

m specific contexts and the impact of context on the articulation of feminist ideas.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Questions such as the following will be explored: Why feminisms as opposed to feminism?How does feminism affect politics and political activity in different countries?(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+These questions will lead to an examination of women's movements around the globe.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 337 - Internship in Sociology (0-15) Field experiences that provide practical applications in appropriate work settings.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing and permission fo the Division of Social Sciences Chair.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

the Division of Social Sciences Chair.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SOC 349 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing, SLS 301.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 352 - Senior Study II (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 352 is the second course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

tudy requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 352 is the second course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The courses involve individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.Ordinarily taken in the fall term of the senior year and preceded by 351 in the spring term of the junior year.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: SOC 351, ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing, SLS 301.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SOC 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

perience in independent research and the preparation of a finished paper or product.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) 246| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.SOC 401 - Social Theory (3) An examination of classical and contemporary theories of the nature of society and human behavior.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course integrates materials from the various sub- disciplines and provides a theoretical and philosophical framework for the discipline.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Senior standing and nine hours in sociology, or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN-Spanish SPN 110 - Elementary Spanish I (4) An introduction to Spanish designed to give students the linguistic, cultural, and geographical background necessary to provide for basic needs when traveling to a Spanish- speaking country.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

necessary to provide for basic needs when traveling to a Spanish- speaking country.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Emphasis is also given to conversing in basic Spanish within well-defined contexts, to reading short passages, and writing simple sentences in Spanish.Cultural and linguistic concepts are reinforced by means of a variety of practical applications.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Offered: Fall, May Term, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 120 - Elementary Spanish II (4) A sequel to Spanish 110, designed to increase knowledge of the basic language, culture and geography of the Hispanic world.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is given to increasing students' capacity to converse, read, and write in Spanish.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Cultural and linguistic concepts are reinforced by means of a variety of practical applications.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into the course or SPN 110.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 201 - Intermediate Spanish (3) An expansion of the grammar, culture, and vocabulary studied in elementary Spanish.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

An expansion of the grammar, culture, and vocabulary studied in elementary Spanish.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Linguistic tasks studied include describing, narrating, and giving opinions and information on a variety of topics.Emphasis is also given to strengthening reading and writing skills through a study of authentic texts and short films.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students learn to speak and write sentences of greater structural sophistication that are logically connected in paragraph-length discourse.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into the course or SPN 120.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 202 - Intermediate Spanish Grammar and Writing (3) A sequel to Spanish 201, designed to increase students' mastery of intermediate and advanced grammatical concepts and writing ability.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+In addition, culture-related readings in Spanish will provide opportunities to learn new vocabulary and grammar in context by means of in-class discussions and compositions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

vocabulary and grammar in context by means of in-class discussions and compositions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Placement into the course or SPN 201.Corequisite: SPN 203.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 203 - Conversational Spanish (3) A course designedto develop speaking skills in Spanish by building on practical vocabulary and grammatical structures studied in previous courses.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Conversational skills on a variety of topics and in a variety of situations are stressed in order to prepare students planning to study abroad.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 201 or the equivalent.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Corequisite: SPN 202 - Intermediate Spanish Grammar and Writing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SPN 305 - Civilizations & Cultures of Latin America (3) A survey of the historical, cultural, geographic, artistic, and political structures of Latin America through reading, discussion, and presentation.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 202 or SPN 203 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 306 - Civilizations & Cultures of Spain (3) A survey of the historical, cultural, geographic, artistic, and political structures of Spain through reading, discussion, and presentation.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 202 or SPN 203 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 310 - Advanced Spanish Language (3) A course in Spanish where all language skills—speaking, Courses| 247 listening, reading, and writing—are treated at an advanced proficiency level.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s| 247 listening, reading, and writing—are treated at an advanced proficiency level.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ The course targets advanced language vocabulary, expressions, usages, and collocations, which are useful for comprehension and production.The course also targets typical grammatical structures that pose difficulties to populations where Spanish is not or has not been the dominant language in any of the skills targeted.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Prerequisite: Either SPN 202, SPN 203, or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 313 - Topics in Spanish Peninsular Literature (3) Selected texts from the medieval period to contemporary Spain.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will examine these texts and contextualize them within literary, historical, social, and political trends.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 304 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 314 - Topics in Latin American Literature (3) Selected texts from the pre-Columbian and colonial periods to contemporary Latin America.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ted texts from the pre-Columbian and colonial periods to contemporary Latin America.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will examine these texts and contextualize them within literary, historical, social, and political trends.(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 304 or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 337 - Internship (3) On- or off-campus experience that provides a linguistic and cultural opportunity for students who wish to acquire practical knowledge of Spanish beyond the intermediate level.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0-15 credit hours.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Major requirement, 3 credit hours) Prerequisite: SPN 202.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 349 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

s from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 351 - Senior Study I (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 351 is the first course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a formal paper.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, HUM 347, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 352 - Senior Study II (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a two- course sequence, 352 is the second course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The courses involve individual study with the guidance of a faculty supervisor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

!)\s+The courses involve individual study with the guidance of a faculty supervisor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Ordinarily taken in the fall term of the senior year and preceded by 351 in the spring term of the junior year.(3 credit hours each) Prerequisite: SPN 351, ENG 120 or equivalent, HUM 347, pass the English Proficiency Exam, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SPN 353 - Senior Study (3) When the Senior Study requirement is fulfilled with a one- course sequence, that experience is designated 353.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Individual study, with the guidance of a faculty supervisor, that provides experience in independent research and the preparation of a formal paper.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+STA-Statistics STA 120 - Introductory Statistics (4) The course develops the analytical skills necessary in the collection, organization, visualization, and interpretation of data.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ecessary in the collection, organization, visualization, and interpretation of data.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Topics include statistical inference for a single proportion, single mean, comparison of two proportions, comparison of two means, and correlation and regression.In addition to theory-based methods, the course develops probabilistic intuition and statistical reasoning through use of simulation to conduct randomization tests.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is given to how study design and data collection determine the scope of inference.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The laboratory component emphasizes the use of statistical software for data analysis and visualization.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(4 credit hours) Prerequisite: MTH 110 or satisfactory performance on the quantitative literacy assessment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

the quantitative literacy assessment.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ 248| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 SUS-Sustainability SUS 101 - Environmental Issues and Foundations of Sustainability (3) An introduction to the origins and interrelationships of major contemporary environmental issues, such as global climate change, sustainable development, population, ozone depletion, deforestation, energy, and water pollution.The course examines the complexity of the issues in environmental, political, social, and economic terms.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This interdisciplinary course will use sustainability concepts, theories, and applications as avenues for approaching and practicing various ways of viewing our planet.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SUS 149 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

equisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ SUS 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SUS 337 - Internship in Sustainability Studies (3) An experiential and/or practical experience enabling students to apply classroom knowledge in work settings.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Internship proposals require faculty approval.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The work experience is expected to take place during the student's junior or senior year.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SUS337 may not be counted for an internship in the Environmental Studies major.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+SUS 349 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ See Course Description in Highlander Hub.SUS 401 - Sustainability E-Portfolio (1) Each student will be expected to collect and reflect on coursework, internship, and research and develop these reflective resources into an e-portfolio The e-portfolio is expected to be submitted within a semester of the student's completion of all other requirements for the Sustainability Studies minor or concurrently with the last remaining requirement of the program.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students are referred to program faculty for detailed portfolio guidelines.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT-Theatre Studies THT 101 - Introduction to Theatre (3) An introduction to Theatre tailored to Theatre majors and minors, with particular attention given to creating a common vocabulary, emphasizing the collaborative nature of theatre, and introducing students to the techniques used when reading and analyzing dramatic literature from the theatre practitioner's perspective.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ading and analyzing dramatic literature from the theatre practitioner's perspective.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) Offered: Fall.THT 140 - Perspectives in Theatre (3) Offered as a topic of study within theatre, this course engages students in an artistic process where historical and cultural contexts are examined and considered.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course topic is approached in terms of both form and content, as students work toward an understanding of the relationship between the two.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Also explored are theatre's values in and to society, which include the importance of arts education and advocacy within and beyond one's community.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 149 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ THT 204 - Theatre Production (1) Course credit given to any student who is cast or works in a major technical capacity for the semester's main stage, faculty- directed production.The designated class session is used for production meetings, but the work involved includes accepting assignments necessary to mount the production.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Guidelines for accountability are set by the faculty director.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course is offered on an S/U basis only.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+May be repeated for credit.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+May not be taken in the same semester with THT 304.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1 credit hour) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Courses| 249 THT 208 - Playwriting (3) Students will explore first-hand the art and craft of writing for the stage by creating their own monologues, scenes, and short plays.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

of writing for the stage by creating their own monologues, scenes, and short plays.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Topics will include finding one's own distinct artistic voice, the revision process, and the creation of engaging stories, dynamic characters, and believable dialogue.(3 credit hours) THT 209 - Play Analysis (3) A course designed to help students understand the basic nature of dramatic literature by examining prominent dramatic theory, beginning with in-depth study of Aristotle's Poetics followed by a survey of dominant trends throughout theatre history, and to examine how playwrights have responded to current thinking in their period.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Representative plays will be read and analyzed from the theatre practitioner's point of view.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: THT 101.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 211 - Stagecraft (3) An introduction to the six elements of stagecraft, which include design and execution of set, lighting, costumes and make-up, as well as theatre and stage management.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ion of set, lighting, costumes and make-up, as well as theatre and stage management.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will select two of these six areas for special concentration during the term.The course consists of both classroom study and applied stagecraft.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The time and type of applied work are arranged with instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 213 - Fundamentals of Theatrical Design (3) Introduces students to the fundamentals of the design process in theatre.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+It emphasizes the aesthetic choices designers make in order to serve the script and maintain artistic unity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Consideration will also be given to providing practical solutions to design and budget challenges, as well as the methods and materials used by theatrical designers for communicating design choices.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 214 - Lighting Design (3) A hands-on approach to the study of lighting for the theatre.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

- Lighting Design (3) A hands-on approach to the study of lighting for the theatre.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will explore the techniques and technologies used in lighting, including electricity, instrumentation, and computerized light boards.In addition to these technological aspects, the course will also explore the aesthetic considerations of creating an effective lighting design, such as the conceptual and storytelling aspects of light.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) THT 215 - Audio Production (3) An introduction to industry-standard techniques and technologies used in sound design, reinforcement, and audio recording.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The course combines a theoretical overview of sound system function, design, construction, and maintenance with practical-use approaches geared toward both musical and theatrical performance.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

with practical-use approaches geared toward both musical and theatrical performance.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ (3 credit hours) THT 216 - Scene Design (3) An exploration of the practical and artistic considerations of scene design; the course emphasizes the set designer's tasks of completing thorough script analysis, period research, and an appropriate design concept.Students will also practice the communication methods used by designers, such as renderings, ground plans, computer- aided drafting, and models.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) THT 217 - Costume Design (3) An in-depth study of the process of designing and making costumes.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Course emphases include script analysis, period research, concept development, and rendering.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will also get hands-on experience making costumes, such as sewing, pattern making, and draping.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

sewing, pattern making, and draping.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ THT 221 - Acting I: Physical and Vocal Preparation (3) An introduction to the fundamentals of stage movement and vocal production for actors, focusing on the body as the primary vehicle for creative expression.Emphasis is on acquiring skills through problem-solving exercises, improvisational games, monologues, and scene work.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 222 - Acting II: Creating the Character (3) An introduction to acting fundamentals and selected rehearsal and performance skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is on exploring the actor's relationship to the dramatic text, to the stage environment, and to the elements of the actor's instrument (body, voice, imagination).(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: THT 221.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 223 - Voice and Movement (3) This course gives particular emphasis to the actor's primary instruments: the voice and the body.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ives particular emphasis to the actor's primary instruments: the voice and the body.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Class exercises and activities encourage the actor to express characters more 250| Maryville College Academic Catalog 2025-2026 effectively through heightened awareness and more intentional use of these two instruments.(3 credit hours) THT 224 - Improvisation for the Theatre (3) An introduction to short-form improvisation and theatre exercises with the intention of honing the actor's creative instincts, increasing spontaneity, and developing team- building skills.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The study of improvisation prepares actors for both scripted and non-scripted work, as well as for auditions.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 225 - Acting for the Camera (3) Through film and television scenes, as well as audition materials, students will explore the techniques employed by actors performing in front of a camera.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

ents will explore the techniques employed by actors performing in front of a camera.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Students will also explore acting challenges specific to the camera, such as shooting out of sequence, reaction shots, and adapting facial expressions and gestures in order to make the transition from stage acting to screen acting.(3 credit hours) THT 226 - Acting in Shakespeare (3) Through film and television scenes, as well as audition materials, students will explore the techniques employed by actors performing in front of a camera.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Students will also explore acting challenges specific to the camera, such as shooting out of sequence, reaction shots, and adapting facial expressions and gestures in order to make the transition from stage acting to screen acting.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) THT 249 - Selected Topics (1-4) Course content varies from year to year to meet the special interests, abilities, and needs of students.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1–4 credit hours) Prerequisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

equisite: Varies by course.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+See Course Description in Highlander Hub.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring.THT 299 - Professional Practices in Theatre (1) Activities and topics that prepare students for issues related to professional work in the field.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Topics will include audition techniques, portfolio preparation, headshots, resumes, unions, professional organizations, legal and ethical issues, and promotion.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(1 credit hour) Offered: Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 304 - Advanced Theatre Production (2) Course credit given to students who work as a stage manager or as a crew head for the semester's main stage, faculty-directed production.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The designated class session is used for production meetings, but the work involved includes accepting assignments necessary to mount the production.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

the work involved includes accepting assignments necessary to mount the production.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Additionally, stage managers and crew heads are expected to lead crews of students, maintain clear lines of communication between all members of the production team, and attend weekly production meetings outside of class.Guidelines for accountability are set by the faculty director.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+This course is offered on an S/U basis only.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+May be repeated for credit.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+May not be taken in the same semester with THT 204.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(2 credit hours) Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 311 - Directing (3) A study of the modern theatre director, directing techniques, styles and methodology.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Emphasis is on current trends in directing, terminology, and practical experience in script analysis, production design, and actual direction of an extended scene or full one-act play for public performance.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: THT 204 (2 semesters minimum), THT 209, and THT 221.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: THT 204 (2 semesters minimum), THT 209, and THT 221.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ Offered: Fall, Spring.THT 315 - American Theatre History (3) THT 316 - Theatre History I (3) This course traces the evolution of the theatre arts (stagecraft, acting and directing) from their ancient Greek origins through the end of the 17th century.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+While the primary emphasis is on Western theatre, non-Western theatre traditions will also be considered.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+THT 317 - Theatre History II (3) This course traces the evolution of the theatre arts (stagecraft, acting and directing) from the 18th century through the contemporary theatre.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+While the primary emphasis is on Western theatre, non- Western theatre traditions will also be considered.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(3 credit hours) Prerequisite: Junior standing or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

nior standing or permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ THT 337 - Internship (7-15) Work in professional or semiprofessional Theatre, intensive training and/or workshops, or significant leadership in an on-campus theatrical activity (such as directing the Alpha Psi Omega annual production or working with the staff of the Clayton Center for the Arts and/or one of the artists in residence at the Clayton Center Courses| 251 for the Arts for one semester), under the supervision of a faculty member and subject to approval by the Chair of the Fine Arts Division.For each credit hour granted students are expected to be involved in at least 45 hours of approved activity.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+The duration should normally occur over a minimum of three weeks.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+(0 to 15 credit hours) Prerequisite: Completion of a minimum 5 hours in Theatre coursework, or junior standing and permission of the instructor.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+

e: ENG 120 or equivalent, pass the English Proficiency Examination, junior standing.(?<=\.|\?|\!)\s+ WRC-World Cultures WRC 370 - Topics in World Culture (3) An examination of the peoples and customs of a particular culture that lies outside of the traditionally understood "Western World."
